text: Old World monkeys are all simian primates. They are more closely related to the apes than they are to the New World monkeys. == Taxonomic classification == * Infraorder Simiiformes ** Parvorder Catarrhini *** Superfamily Cercopithecoidea **** Family Cercopithecidae: Old World monkeys ***** Subfamily Cercopithecinae ****** Tribe Cercopithecini ******* Genus Allenopithecus ******* Genus Miopithecus ******* Genus Erythrocebus ******* Genus Chlorocebus ******* Genus Cercopithecus ****** Tribe Papionini ******* Genus Macaca ******* Genus Lophocebus ******* Genus Rungwecebus ******* Genus Papio ******* Genus Theropithecus ******* Genus Cercocebus ******* Genus Mandrillus ***** Subfamily Colobinae ****** African group ******* Genus Colobus ******* Genus Piliocolobus ******* Genus Procolobus ****** Langur (leaf monkey) group ******* Genus Semnopithecus ******* Genus Trachypithecus ******* Genus Presbytis ****** Odd-nosed group ******* Genus Pygathrix ******* Genus Rhinopithecus ******* Genus Nasalis ******* Genus Simias ==Key== {| class="wikitable" |style="background:#e3e3e3"|Scientific name |Latin binomial name, or Latin name, of the species |- |style="background:#e3e3e3"|Common name |Common name of the species, per Wilson, et al. Mammal Species of the World (2005) |- |style="background:#e3e3e3"|Classified |Date in which the species was formally described and classified, as well as the binomial authority on the species |- |style="background:#e3e3e3"|Average size |Average size of adult members of the species, in metric and English weight units |- |style="background:#e3e3e3"|Estimated size |Estimated average size of adult members of the extinct species |- |style="background:#e3e3e3"|Conservation status |Conservation status of the species, per IUCN as of 2008 |- |style="background:#e3e3e3"|Extinction date |Year of extinction or estimated date range for subfossil species, in BCE/CE |- |} == Extant species == === Subfamily: Cercopithecinae === ==== Tribe: Cercopithecini ==== {| class="wikitable sortable" !style="background:#e3e3e3"|Scientific name !style="background:#e3e3e3"|Common name !style="background:#e3e3e3"|Classified !style="background:#e3e3e3"|Male average size !style="background:#e3e3e3"|Female average size !style="background:#e3e3e3"|Conservation status !style="background:#e3e3e3" class="unsortable"|References |- |Allenopithecus nigroviridis |Allen's swamp monkey |1907 Pocock | | | | |- |Miopithecus talapoin |Angolan talapoin |1774 Schreber | | | | |- |Miopithecus ogouensis |Gabon talapoin |1997 Kingdon | | | | |- |Erythrocebus patas |patas monkey |1775 Schreber | | | | |- |Chlorocebus sabaeus |green monkey |1758 Linnaeus | | | | |- |Chlorocebus aethiops |grivet |1758 Linnaeus | | | | |- |Chlorocebus djamdjamensis |Bale Mountains vervet |1902 Neumann | | | | |- |Chlorocebus tantalus |tantalus monkey |1841 Ogilby | | | | |- |Chlorocebus pygerythrus |vervet monkey |1821 F.
